newsitem.title: UK: LME copper fails to sustain upward move.
newsitem.headline: LME copper fails to sustain upward move.

text.p: LME copper ended Tuesday with muted gains after strength to attack overhead barriers evaporated.

As prices approached the key $1,970 per tonne level on the first afternoon ring, selling came in, stalling the advance at $1,968, as profit-taking and producer selling overwhelmed buyers, dealers said.
It was disappointing that the market could not even stay above the $1,950 level, ending only $11 higher at $1,945, they added.

The market has been wary of the recent LME stocks falls, including Tuesday's 10,950-tonne decline, since many believe tonnage is not destined for end users. Many say it is ending up in bonded Chinese warehouses, where is liable to be re-expored.
"Switching stock from one hand to another by sleight of hand, however, deftly done, unfortunately does not make it disappear," said Nick Moore of Flemings Global Mining Group.
"We continue to counsel a risk averse stance towards copper, preferring exposure to aluminium, nickel and zinc," he added in a commentary.
Aluminium broke through several layers of resistance as influential short-covering hit the market, but eased off its afternoon high of $1,363.
Last business on the kerb was at $1,356, a healthy $30 gain from Monday.

But some technical analysts have been cautious, saying a bounce was expected after the market dived into oversold territory when touching $1,305 recently, adding that charts look vulnerable to a solid test of the $1,300 level in the near future.
Lead recovered from its slide to seven-month lows of $735 on Monday, ending the kerb at $750, up $12. Resistance is pegged at $760/1.
Tin also finished the day stronger at $6,000, up from $5,975 on Monday, but off its high of $6,015.
Nickel ended unchanged at $7,120 after exploring within a range of $7,155 to $7,100.
Zinc gained $7 to $1,022, just on the cusp of resistance.
